instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / Stuck at 20V 0.05amps
threads.message:
Hi there,

We have a new Apple Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> which does not power up, no fans, no chime and black screen. We tested USB C port and the results are below: 

1. when the board on Apple MacBook Pro connected to the battery --> 20v 0.05amps. Amps goes up to 0.60-0.70 and loops back to 0amps and again again. 
2. when board directly connect to the charging cable --> 20v 0.05amps

In this situation where we should start from to test and measure voltage. Does it look like firmware corruption T2 level or looks like to certain chips/elements shorted?

Please advise. Thank you. 

Regards,
Zack

Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / Stuck at 20V 0.05amps
threads.message:
only motherboard:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>                               - 12.6 V
<SIGNAL>P3V3_G3H_RTC_DEBUG_LED_R</SIGNAL> - 0 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_REG_R</SIGNAL>            - 3.38 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL>                    - 3.38 V

threads.title: Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / Stuck at 20V 0.05amps
threads.message:
Check all expected SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages.
If OK, try DFU...

threads.title: Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / Stuck at 20V 0.05amps
threads.message:
P1V1SLPS2R_SW0 - 1.1 V
P1V1SLPS2R_SW1 - 1.1 V

P1V8SLPS2R_FB - 1.8 V
P1V8SLPS2R_SW0 - 1.8 V
<SIGNAL>P1V8_SLPS2RSW_DFR_R</SIGNAL> - 0 V

<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 0.8 V
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_SLPS2R_SMC_AVREF</SIGNAL> - 1.25 V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 1.8 V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R_SOC_LPADC_RC</SIGNAL> - 1.8 V
<SIGNAL>SOC_RED_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 0 V

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - 1.2 V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - 1.8 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - 3.3 V
<SIGNAL>SOC_BLUE_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - 0 V

Is it ok ?

thank you

threads.title: Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / Stuck at 20V 0.05amps
threads.message:
If you have steady SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages, machine should enter DFU.
You may need to force it (wire method).
[URL unfurl="true"]https://logi.wiki/index.php/DFU_Mode_Restore_(Macs)[/URL]

threads.title: Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / Stuck at 20V 0.05amps
threads.message:
We can enter DFU mode, but Apple Configurator reviving stuck for about 10 minutes and then shows an error.
screenshots attached

threads.title: Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / Stuck at 20V 0.05amps
threads.message: Now it shows(immediately) same error but at the end "... - 0xB(11)]"

threads.title: Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / Stuck at 20V 0.05amps
threads.message:
Many times revive doesn't help.
Data is probably lost anyway, but first confirm with customer if you can erase the SSD.
Then try restore.
